author: valentinepeter

title: Prusa i3 MK3 - Cooling with a view

description.text:
I found a way to improve the cooling AND improve the view of the nozzle AND simplify nozzle changes! Win, win, win. Wait! There's more: now with garter screw! What's that? It holds up your sock. Screw in M3x18 to provide light touch to hold upper lip of e3d sock.

One thing that has always annoyed me about the original Prusa printers is the way the part cooling is attached to the extruder blocks the view of the nozzle printing. I can't tell you how many times I have been able to diagnose a bad/failed print by observing how the nozzle is laying down plastic. I also didn't like that you need to partially disassemble for nozzle changes. So I set out to get 360 degree cooling while fixing these problems. I also stumbled on a simple solution for keeping the silicone sock from dragging on the print which has many surprising (not in a good way) side effects.

Still tweaking so check back for updates.

2/05/18 update: several improvements to air flow, printing, fit, strength. There are reports of the factory shroud sagging from high temp printing. This design is less susceptible due to larger surface area and multiple contact points. Nevertheless, I reinforced and added an optional clip for the back corner. Also built-in supports so no need to add in slicer. Brace is now optional and compatible with my laser mod.

I recommend print in 0.15 layer with 3 perimeters and 40% infill.

First remove factory nozzle and fan. Next mount new nozzle starting with PINDA first, then pulling inlet slightly to allow pin to insert into old nozzle screw hole. Important to make sure nozzle is level. It should be flush with PINDA mount and small circle spacer on other side should be flush with bottom of extruder. You may need to tuck up heater wire and make sure zip tie is rotated out of the way. Finally add clip in rear as shown in photo. Optional, but recommended, use needle nose pliers to add clip in back corner between hook on nozzle and x-carriage bearing holder (see photo).

Now screw new nozzle loosely to old upper fan hole using M3x10 from original nozzle. Next Insert fan outlet into nozzle inlet (will be snug) and attach the fan to the mounting arm with hex nuts using original M3x18 screws, loosely. Now go back and tighten all screws, making sure fan stays in inlet. Note that you may need to slacken the fan wire some if you snugged it tight on first install.

Last, you need to replace the factory heated cable cover with the lower profile one supplied here. This should be a straight-forward swap: cut zip, unscrew, pull out filament, insert in new cover, screw down, adding spacer to front screw under bed. Spacer keeps screw tip flush.

[Save this step until you are satisfied with new nozzle, and it is optional, but adds garter screw; get this part from my laser mod project]. Note when removing extruder cover you may find it stuck. This is due to screw from back side tapping in. You can pry off but be careful. Bonus is this should be the last time you remove it. New cover has clearance built in and installs exactly like original.

NOTE you should remove the nozzle if you need to do a full XYZ calibration (rare to never) because without the steel sheet you can rub the back pins.

remixed_from.author: DDStarkey
remixed_from.title: Replacement Stepper Drives for Replicator Dual Extruder

description.text:
I got my hands on a Replicator 2 and the MightyBoard Rev H with a missing botstep and 3 blown BOTSTEP17Es ($50), so I went the Pololu 2128 S4988 Stepper Motor Driver, Black Edition ($6.95) with the 68mΩ sense resistors, which is the version made since Jan 2017.

I took voltage measurements of my working Rep 2s (Mightyboard Rev G & H) and carefully studied the schematic and datasheets of the A4982 (Botstep17E) & A4988 (Pololu 2128) to determine the following conclusions:

  1. MS1 & MS2 are given +5V on all BOTSTEPs, which means the Mightyboard is doing 1/16 steps. MS3 on the A4988 should also be tied to +5V.

  2. The Z motor Botstep's Vref into the A4982 is being fed 0.70V (Mightyboard Rev H). This equates to an Imax of 0.33A. Mightyboard Rev G measured 0.73V => 0.34A.

  3. To get Imax on the Pololu 2128 (Jan 2017 or later version) to be 0.33A, adjust the potentiometer to 0.18V.

  4. The X, Y and Extruder motor Botstep's Vrefs into the A4982 are being fed 1.68V (Mightyboard Rev H). This equates to an Imax of 0.78A. Mightyboard Rev G measured 1.70V => 0.79A.

  5. To get Imax on the Pololu 2128 (Jan 2017 or later version) to be 0.78A, adjust the potentiometer to 0.42V.

  6. The A4982 and A4988 are basically the same chips, performance wise (most values are identical, including RDSon and have the same package thermal characteristics). The key differences are as follows:
    • The A4982 has a sleep mode
    • The A4988 has a 1/8 step mode and a 3rd mode select pin (MS3)
    • Both chips are available in difference IC packages

Tips:
a. Getting to the Vref trim pot is impossible when put into breadboard or Mightyboard. Must use trial by error to get the voltages correct.

b. Remove the header pin for MS3 and jump MS3 to MS2 with a small wire or solder blob.

c. Label the Z axis module as Z Axis Only with a silver sharpie

d. Put heat sinks on the X, Y & Extruder modules.

WARNING:
The reason the Mightyboard is feeding Vref a voltage to the BotSteps is to allow it to adjust the hold current on the stepper motors. This lets them save power during heating up the extruder. So while the extruder is heating up, the steppers can be drawing less power. This can be seen in the start.gcode with a G130 command.

I might not recommend these replacements drivers if you have a heated build plate and the stock 150W power supply. The power draw for the build plate, extruder and steppers may exceed what the power supply can deliver.I would advise using a stiff 24V 300W or higher power supply.

These have been working fine in a Replicator 2, no heated bed with stock power supply.

description.text:
This is a filter holder designed to hold the Juwel BioFlow One filter. I made it because within a year the 4 suction cups of the filter will become hard and won't hold the filter to the glass anymore.

You can slide this holder around the filter and then clip it to the glass so it will be held into position again without needing the suction cups. You do need to leave the suction cups mounted; the holder will be kept in place between the suction cups. The holder is easy to remove when you are cleaning the filter.

The print is easy, but be sure your build plate is large enough. It is best printed laying down on it's side. The original source file and a dxf export are included if you want to modify this holder.

author: oregontrailmike

description.text:
Nothing too special here, just a simple towel rack for a single hand towel. A lot of other designs require separate material for the bar, presumably to save on print time and plastic. However, my concern was laziness, so I chose to let my printer do the work and print out the bar for me.

The bar has about 0.2mm shaved off on each side so that it hopefully fits snugly in the holders. You may have to scale it down if you have a lower resolution printer. Alternatively, a little sandpaper on the corners will shave it down to size just fine.

The mounting holes are just accessible enough that you can get a screwdriver in there. I mounted mine with 1 inch wallboard screws.

This was my third or fourth project in Fusion 360. If you haven't used it before, I recommend it. It's not open-source or free (as in speech or as in beer), but it's a very nice and powerful piece of software, and it has a free tier for non-professional use.

title: stacked gears for quick change gearbox

description.text:
if you have an old imperial hobby sized lathe and would like to make either a light duty gearbox or make castings for metal gears then these along with a few of the original sizes will be handy to have about, the original designer supplied the gear set as individual gears to my specs and ive combined the gears to make the compounds here to make life easier for everyone else, check his thing out you will need a couple of other bits from his design and if you want the rest of the information the article im using as a guide is http://vintagemachinery.org/pubs/51/7158.pdf

edited to add better version of the 32/16 gear as i found the original almost impossible to print with my set up, the gears have already been scaled so they can be printed in mm rather than inches, and i know the 36 gear tooth shape is wrong; i intend on running it in on a steel gear of the right tooth shape so it heats up and melts to the right shape.

description.text:
I developed and created a PCB for a pad that provides the 40% of keys left behind from a full-sized keyboard when you take a 60% keyboard out. This 3D print object is a basic case that supports the PCB.

The tolerances on the print are very tight and some sanding may be required in the switch cutouts to get a good fit. The thickness of the top plate is 3.5mm therefore diode components should be mounted on the PCB away from the plate on the underside, and it is recommended that the diodes are soldered on the underside to prevent the solder joint from pushing on the PCB and case.

A video of the build for this with the case is available here: https://youtu.be/YiW8VHWHLUg

Automatic watch winder for 2 automatic watches and powered by geared motor, servo or raspberry pi zero.

Parts list and tips:

  1. Low noise motor (Option1) and driving geared motor (Option 2)with 10rpm max.
  2. Power switch On/off
  3. Steel pins size to suit gear axle
  4. Bearing (either printed out or steel bearing)
  5. Screws
    Motor Option:
  6. Back-gear_frame.stl
  7. 8 driving gear.stl
  8. 2 Nos. 40x8 -final.stl
    OR Geared Motor (1020555 3K1655)Option:
  9. New_8_gear.stl
  10. New_motor_frame.stl
  11. 1 No. 40x8-final.stl
    Optional controller:
    Method 1:
    Programmable timer and an USB power supplier
    http://www.dx.com/p/digital-lcd-electronic-plug-in-programmable-timer-12-24-hour-switch-socket-with-clock-summer-time-416027#.WkmJJpeYO70
    Method 2:
    Raspberry Pi Zero with a modified relay controller
    https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-power-relay-featherwing/overview?view=all
    Method 3:
    IC 555 delay timer switch
    Method 4:
    TPL5111
    https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-tpl5111-reset-enable-timer-breakout/overview?view=all

Watch cups were fixed with bearing on the back panel and rotated and guarded by front panel. To ensure prefect contact, watch cups shall be heated with hot water or hair dryer and then pull fit into panel and turned for 10+ rounds until smooth to run. Finally, some grease may add on it for easy of turning. For the watches, it was fixed into cups with oval shaped spongy material (cut from heat pipe insulation materials).

Noise may be generated during the operation, please review the specifications of the driving motor for its operation voltage. If it is possible, please use a low noise geared motor as in crystal display stand. IC, LM317 may be used to step down the voltage in order to slow down the driving motor such that noise can be reduced. In my case, 5V USB adopter of mobile phone was used as power with a LM317 to convert voltage to 3.9V with 475 ohm and 1k ohm resistors. It is programmed to run 3 times every day via 7 x 24 hrs. digital timer plug.

Optional functions such as AIY with raspberry pi and powered by USB for mobile docking or charging stand.

If you do not want to print or make one, you may buy a watch winder in below link from me in a more reasonable price.

description.text:
This simple support attaches between a larger end-stop and to the mount holes for Requiem. I mocked this up after breaking my original end-stop on my Tanantala and needed to install a larger one which didn't fit.

The hole positions are based on a SS_5GL Omron microswitch - this is the same as many other popular ones sold also known as Kossel Limit Switches Endstop.

The STL is for the right-sided support but you can simply mirror the axis in your slicer to get a left sided one.

Use 2 x M2 8mm screws to attach the micro-switch,
The pointy ends that go into Requiem just need a little force as they have a tapered shape.

title: Project enclosure for PGA2311 preamp/input switcher kit

description.text:
My stereo receiver/amp was dying, and I decided to replace it with a compact T-class amplifier. However, none of the ones on the market had multiple switchable inputs or a volume remote. Fortunately, looking around I found quite a few eBay sellers who were selling PGA2311-based volume control and input switchers for pretty cheap in the form of a pre-assembled modular kit. However, none of them were complete with all the required parts, and the enclosures available for this kit were both ridiculously expensive (as much as the kit itself) and, frankly, ugly.

So I designed my own enclosure, designed to be printed in whatever color combinations you want. I went with a "creamsicle" theme.

Paired with the amplifier it sounds fantastic. And now I have way more space for records, too!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or higher

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Because of the large footprint this needs a larger printer such as a Makerbot, Prusa i3, Ultimaker, etc.

I printed using PLA.

Other parts you will need to complete the build
  • A center-tap step-down transformer (I used a 110/220 -> ±6VAC, with the mains side wired in parallel for 110)
  • Mounting screws/standoffs (I bought this kit although all you really need is 4x 5mm and 4x 11mm standoffs, 8 nuts, and 10 screws - 8 for the PCBs and 2 for the transformer)
  • Two RCA audio jacks and an appropriate connector for the board (my kit used a JST XH 2.5-3pin, yours may be different)
  • An ungrounded mains power plug and appropriate cord (this case is sized for two prongs although modifying it for a three-prong plug should be straightforward)
Post-printing instructions
  1. Solder the mains rails of the transformer to the power plug, as appropriate to your power configuration; don't forget to shrink-wrap the solder joints!
  2. Fit the power plug into the appropriate opening in the top shell
  3. Attach the 5mm standoffs to the inside of the bottom shell, and screw on some nuts on the outside
  4. Mount the RCA jacks in the bottom shell, and solder the connector to them as appropriate (my board was left-common-right); since mine was a 3-wire connector I had to splice on some wire to put the common to the ground sleeve on both RCA jacks, and for safety I also shrinkwrapped that join
  5. Attach the transformer's step-down rails to the power connector on the preamp PCB, and screw the transformer down to the case bottom
  6. Attach the RCA jacks to the output connector on the main PCB, and screw the PCB down to the standoffs
  7. Attach the 11mm standoffs to the front of the display PCB, and adjust the legs of the IR sensor until it lines up with the sensor hole when the standoffs are flush with the inside of the front of the bottom case
  8. Mount the volume/selector knob to the front panel on the bottom case
  9. Attach the main PCB to the standoffs
  10. Snap the top case in place (be careful to manipulate the cables so that they don't press against the heat sinks or get kinked or whatever) and then screw in the top screws for the display PCB

I used OpenSCAD, and to make my life easier I modeled it in several modules so that I could adjust things and use CSG operations on them to make them automatically update everything. See the .scad file for more information!

The knob is a modified version of my 16mm control knob, done by scaling the knob body by 1.5x in X and Y, and disabling the arrow marker on the base (as the control knob on this preamp does not have a stop position). You can use any 6mm shaft knob that you like, though.

Anyway the actual design process involved a lot of test fitting and mistake making. In fact the version that I "finished" only has the left screws on the front panel, as the right holes were 2mm off! I also didn't put enough clearance for the power jack's latch tab. These problems have been corrected in the files uploaded here, however. Someday if I feel like burning another 400 grams of PLA and 12 hours of print time I may fix this.

title: FPV Monitor & DVR Enclosure + Mount for tripod

description.text:
Tripod neck mount for FPV 5" monitor + DVR for Ground Station.

The motivation for this project came from building a ground station and realizing that people have very messy setups with lot's of wires sticking out. So I decided to make this one unit with only two ports for power and video. You can buy a monitor with built in DVR but that is expensive route and where is the fun in it?. This is fairly inexpensive and elegant setup.
Plan to use Quanum Overlord Diversity on top of the tripod and this module on the side of the tripod connected to Quanum Overlord or another ground station.

The DVR in my Fat Shark goggles stopped working after my Laforge mod and never worked reliably since. So, I bought a cheap DVR. This setup would be good for finding lost models by replaying video in the field + when bystanders are curious about what the heck am I doing? they can watch me fly on the little monitor. The video resolution from FPV TX sucks for viewing on the computer or posting online, but on 5" monitor looks great.

DVR https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019F2JW20/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

5" monitor (Monitor comes with wires coming from the back. - Unslolder the wires and make a hole on the side of the monitor enclosure and route the wires through it, for access to DVR opening.

https://www.ebay.com/itm/5-inch-TFT-LCD-Car-Rear-View-Rearview-Monitor-With-Stand-Reverse-Backup-Camera/282298344204?hash=item41ba4ae30c:g:cGEAAOSwEzxYWeuc

10mm diameter DC power plug
and RCA video without housing.

Used DC to DC adjustable voltage regulator
https://www.ebay.com/itm/5pcs-MP1584-3A-Adjustable-DC-Step-Down-Converter-Buck-Module-3-3V-5V-9V-12V-24V/132416728307?hash=item1ed4a6ecf3:g:hAUAAOSwytJaSTM5

so I can power the whole rig from 12v DC -- DVR requires 5VDC

And lastly, here is the mount for this setup which fits on the neck of the tripod
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748913
This was designed with monitor to be removable and secured with 1/4 20 bolt and a wing nut.

printed all of this with PETG my favorite print material.

title: Prusa MK3, MK2S X-Axis Belt Tensioner

description.text:
I had a difficult time getting the belt tension I was looking for when assembling the MK3 printer. I wanted more adjustment then what is available by rotating the stepper motor when tightening. Once assembled it is also difficult to get back in and tighten the belt on the X-Axis carriage. So I designed a simple plate that mounts to the motor and has slots to allow for tightening the belt. Assemble the plate on to the X-Axis motor with (4x) M3 x 10mm screws, I had these in my Spare Parts Bag. Install (3x) of the square M3 nuts (also in Spare Parts Bag) in the slots then assemble to the mount, leave slightly loose. I used a screw driver between the motor and the frame for leverage to get the belt tight and then fully tightened the 3 screws. I also flipped the pulley on the motor around 180 degrees so the belt was aligned inside the slot.

Update 1/22/18
One of the users who made this for an MK3, needed to increase the center diameter to 1.0in to fit the stepper motor. The center locating diameter on my MK3 stepper motor is 22mm, which is the original bracket STL. I added a second bracket with a 1in center diameter in case anybody else has the same issue.

Notes:

Keep in mind that with the maximum layer height of .2 mm, any layer height above .2 mm and you risk the wheels and propeller fusing with their axles. Set the number of shells/walls to the minimum number as to get the best resolution during printing. Have the supports be external only, no support material should appear between the wheels and the body of the plane.

To create this plane I started by building the right half of the plane, then mirrored it after all the details were finished.
The only part not included in the mirror was the propeller as it would have ended up fused to the body of the plane.

The CAD software I used for creating this plane is Autodesk Inventor Professional 2017.

description.text:
This is a temperature and humidity monitor that I designed based on the ESP8266 microcontroller.

The device also features WiFi capabilities for the purpose of logging the data on a remote server (e.g. a Raspberry Pi). The main parts of the device are of course the ESP8266 microcontroller, a DHT11 temperature and humidity sensor, and a 16x4 character LCD.

The project is fully open source. The PCB design files and the source code for the firmware and the server can be found on GitHub. Checkout my Instructables project for detailed instructions on making your own. The enclosure is designed on FreeCAD and the fcstd files are also available for download.

title: CR-10s leveling wheel for 17.75mm thumb screws

description.text:
This wheel slides over the thumb screws on the CR-10s. I bought my CR-10s on 11/28/2017. The thumb screws on my machine are 17.65-17.80mm in diameter including the little notches that are on there(see picture).

If you have this size thumb screw, you should be able to give this a go.

I have included an "inward" and "outward" version(see picture). Use either you want, mix and match, get nasty with it. Use the test piece to see if your thumb screw fits the .1mm, .15mm, or .2mm offset version. The test piece will print in 10 minutes.

This wheel is a pressfit and fits nice and snug, you may need to lightly sand the very center hole that the thumbscrew fits threw(see picture for how it fits thru).

0% infill will work if your good, but I'd suggest 8% infill, 3 layers of perimeter, 3 layers of bottom and 3 layers of top. The 8% infill could be a problem as far as how the roof 'looks', but it will work. Go for 15% infill or 5 top layers if you want a better looking wheel.

Enjoy!

---EDIT---change the filename when you save to gcode, looks like it doesn't like '.' before a filename.

description.text:
Given that it's nigh impossible to get Box Organizers into Australia without paying through the nose for shipping charges, I've decided to make my own, consisting of ~13 component boxes.

This is currently a work in progress!

My intention is to create a box organizer capable of fitting the standard box that holds all of the content from the standard game plus the Invaders from Afar expansion, plus many of the extra goodies obtained during the Kickstarter project. I expect that:

  • all component boxes without lids will fit inside the standard box with no raising of the box lid;
  • all component boxes and their lids will fit inside the standard box raising the box lid by 2mm;
  • all component boxes without lids and the expansion board will fit inside the standard box raising the box lid by 2mm;
  • all component boxes and their lids and the expansion board will fit inside the standard box raising the box lid by 10mm.

I aim to make elements of the box organizer available as I design, print and prototype them - that way I can obtain feedback on this project while it's in-flight.

What this "thing" currently contains:

  • Seven player piece boxes designed to hold the player pieces for the seven game factions. Each box has the faction name and logo embossed into the box base;
  • Seven lids for the player piece boxes, with each faction's logo cut out from the top to help with identification.

What is still to come for this "thing":

  • A component box and lid to hold the Encounter cards;
  • A component box and lid to hold the Factory and Quick-Start cards;
  • A component box and lid to hold the Automa and Objective cards;
  • A component box and lid to hold the Combat cards and Structure Bonus tiles;
  • A component box and lid to hold all Resource tokens in separate compartments;
  • A component box and lid to hold all Coins in separate compartments;

Final notes.

Progress on this project has been a little slower than I would have liked - a couple of printer breakdowns (including a seized y-axis motor, failed bed levelling sensor and broken filament bearing) have prevented me from testing the lids for the player pieces. I've now printed them all off and am happy with the results. I've designed the card holder for the Factory/Encounter cards and am doing test prints of these as I write this.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I'm currently using the following settings to print these:

  • Layer Height: 0.08mm
  • Initial Layer Height: 0.2mm
  • Wall & Top/Bottom Thickness: 1.6mm
  • Infill Density: 20%

For best results, use a 0.4mm nozzle.

title: Star Trek - Ganine Classic Chess Set: King

description.text:
The cover photo shows 3 sets; original in the back row, full size print in the middle row and 70% prints in the front row.

In each of these uploads, I have included photos which show the printed piece, a 70% sized print (which actually fit under the attack boards) and an original piece, for comparison. For the Bishops and Pawns, when stacking the rings on the base part, I found it useful to drill a hole in the centers to run a length of filament up the center for stability and alignment. I also found that a product called “Plastruct Plastic Weld” works wonders on ABS plastic! It melts ABS, so I could even use it to smooth out the surfaces after assembly, although my wife calls it “stinky glue” so use it in a well ventilated area!

It will take some time to complete a set, but I think the results are worth it. Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: To install, position where desired (Near ESC's, Batteries, motors etc) lightly press around edges to give a slight indentation (Or trace with pen/pencil), cut out required area, test fit, glue in place!

description.text:
A few parts Ive designed for my Flite Test foam board planes.
Intake A - Small Induction Scoop
Exhaust (A,B,C) - Small Vents For Cooling In 3 Different Styles

Printer:

Turnigy Fabrikator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

5

Notes:

Printed in PLA. ABS may work, but I've only printed these parts in PLA. Also, The PLA works well because the hot glue softens it up and gives a very secure glue bond when cooled.

Supports are not needed if your printer can manage small bridges easily. It is also designed so that if there is any sag, it can be trimmed and wont be noticed in the overall finish. Print "upside" down. Rotate so the top of the intake/vent is on print bed.

To install, position where desired (Near ESC's, Batteries, motors etc) lightly press around edges to give a slight indentation (Or trace with pen/pencil), cut out required area, test fit, glue in place!

description.text:
This is an electronics enclosure that I needed for a small tank track robot platform.
You can pay full price for one like I did here: https://www.amazon.com/mountain-ark-Tracked-Platform-Aluminum/dp/B0746FTL9Z

Or you can save some money but wait:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DOIT-Mini-T100-metal-robot-tank-car-chassis-crawler-caterpiller-tracked-vehich-with-plastic-track-diy/32815488700.html

For mounting screws, I used #6-32x1.5" but an M4x40 should also work. In fact any length over 3/4" / 20mm should be fine.

NOTE: I had to use a spacer nut to get the type of clearance I wanted, otherwise the tracks may slightly touch the bottom.

Our fish were getting over-fed due to not knowing if someone had fed them at the right time.

This was a simple solution to show when they were last fed.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the base pieces with the "U" part vertically.  They don't need much infill. I used supports for the holster's tabs and the base pieces' tab slots, though they may be unnecessary.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is a remix of IROTRAS's Glue Stick Dispenser, which was a remix of Justblair's Parametric Cylindrical Battery Dispenser.

I updated it to work with the larger 22g (.77oz) Elmer's purple disappearing glue sticks (that are 27mm in diameter by 103mm long). It should be able to hold 5, maybe 6 in the main dispenser plus the current one that's being used in the holster.

Since it's a bit larger to accommodate the larger sticks, I removed material to reduce print times and plastic usage. I also changed the screw to countersunk flat heads, since that's what I had on hand.

Update 01/25/2018: Per ni2o's suggestion, I added a custom hook to use this with a pegboard. It's made for 1/4 in. holes and a 1 in. hole spacing. It's a modified version of Nightcrispy's Pegboard Hooks. Printing off two hooks holds it pretty well. Attach them around either the top or bottom rung on the back.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print the base pieces with the "U" part vertically. They don't need much infill. I used supports for the holster's tabs and the base pieces' tab slots, though they may be unnecessary.
You might need to sand the holster tabs to get them to fit in the slots. I super glued the holster to the side and the base pieces to each other.

title: Braille numbers, 1-12 in Nemeth code with number sign

description.text:
DO NOT RESIZE or SCALE! Changes in size can render braille unintelligible.  
These are simple number labels using Nemeth code (the US standard code for brailing mathematics).  All numbers have the number sign preceding the digit.  
These are for use in applying braille labels to dials, rulers, measuring tools so that they are accessible to the blind.  If doing so it is important to leave a precise tactile mark similar to a ruler.  Center the digit or place the marker on the backwards L shaped symbol (called the number sign).

author: jaqtikkun

description.text:
I tried the cup holder here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2364780
Unfortunately it was too large to print on my printer when scaled for the size of cups I use. During this holiday break I needed a project to help me learn how to use Fusion 360, so I made this 2-piece design.

The upper ring is designed with a 5 degree taper which I found matches many typical drinking cups and glasses. You can adjust the scale to print the size that fits your cups, bottles, cans or coozies.

For strength I suggest 3-4 perimeters and heavy infill for the ring, and 2-3 perimeters and heavy infill for the stand. If the stand doesn't snap into the ring, simply increase or decrease the scale to fit. On my printer the stand had to be printed at 98.5% to get a snug fit. I glue all my 3D printed parts using IPS Weld-On #16 Acrylic solvent cement.

I used glow-in-the-dark PLA from Atomic for the ring shown in the pictures.

A southwest saguaro designed as a shell (about .8mm). Best printed with a translucent filament. Has a LED mount on the bottom. I printed with no support even though I got some artifacts under the arms, easily scraped off. Designed at 280mm height. Enjoy.

title: Dual E3D V6 Bowden Head w/Extrusion Cooling

description.text:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2731704

So I should do what I want with it?
Ok, then I redesigned the holder so that you can attach the Tassimo boxes to any refrigerator or any other metallic surface. Six square magnets with 5mm x 5mm x 5mm are required. They are simply pressed into the holes and held without glue.

In version 2 (green) I removed the bridge at the bottom. After a few tests it turned out that the 4 pins are enough to hold the boxes.

Ich soll also damit machen was ich will?
Ok, dann habe ich den Halter mal umgestaltet so das man die Tassimo Kartons an jedem Kühlschrank oder einer sonstigen metallischen Oberfläche anheften kann. Es werden sechs viereckige Magneten mit 5mm x 5mm x 5mm benötigt. Die werden einfach in die Löcher dafür gedrückt und halten ohne Kleber.

In Version 2 (grün) habe ich den Steg an der Unterseite entfernt. Nach einigen Tests hat sich herausgestellt das die 4 Pins ausreichen um die Boxen zu halten.

author: BigScaryBlackDude

description.text:
When he was President, Theodore Roosevelt often encouraged friends and family to get out into nature. At the American Museum of Natural History, we share Roosevelt's passion for the natural world, and we want you to go outdoors and start exploring.   
Start by downloading and printing your own TinyTR. Then plan your own expedition to a park or anywhere else you experience nature and take a photo of your own TinyTR. Tweet it with #TinyTR to @AMNH.

The American Museum of Natural History's Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Hall features an exhibition charting Theodore Roosevelt's journey from a budding naturalist exploring the Museum's halls to an elected leader with a deep commitment to conservation. At the center of the hall, a new bronze sculpture of Theodore Roosevelt, depicted as he looked during a famous 1903 camping trip to Yosemite with naturalist John Muir, invites visitors to sit next to TR and contemplate his pioneering role in conservation and the vital importance of protecting nature today. Near the sculpture, a new bronze medallion embedded in the floor depicts American bison grazing in Theodore Roosevelt National Park in the North Dakota Badlands with the inscription, "There can be no greater issue than that of conservation in this country," an excerpt from Roosevelt'ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂs Confession of Faith speech delivered at the Progressive National Convention in Chicago on August 6, 1912. These TinyTeddys are scans of the new bronze sculpture. >>teddy_newcut.stl is a lower res version with shoulders and no logos, but has a wide flat base and can be printed without supports!<< More information can be found here:
http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/current-exhibitions/theodore-roosevelt-memorial/theodore-roosevelt-memorial-hall

title: Idol of Many Hands from Monkey Island

description.text:
This is an homage to the hilarious Monkey Island series where you nudge Guybrush all around to romp on his crazy adventures!

One of the most hilarious bit was the Idol of Many Hands, and something which we just had to somehow bring to life. And so we did!

Presenting the fabled idol here, in all its glorious and not so names-worthy 3d state - ready for 3d printing and gold plating or making a solid gold version of. Whichever floats your boat.

Have fun with this one, rrrrrr! =)

===

All rights for the original design belong to and are derived from the Monkey Island game by LucasArts.

This model is not to be uploaded or sold in any form and is intended for personal use only.

Check out more of what we are up to over at our Facebook Page (http://www.facebook.com/FunbieStudios) or website (http://www.FunbieStudios.com)

description.text:
I keep my PS4 on a shelf with height restrictions preventing it from being put on its side.
I noticed heat building up between the bottom of the PS4 and the shelf, near the back, so I printed corner feet to lift the case form the shelf and allow air flow under it.

It sits on these feet without adhesives, if you aren't moving it around, changing plugs etc, but I think some double-sided tape would help hold them in place if necessary.

description.text:
A maker space is never complete without any fast method to prototype a Electronics project. And the longest process in it is to make the PCBs. Till now I have been using the Toner transfer method and Ferric Chloride. You can watch a video I made here. Etching method involves many steps. The printing, transfer, corrections after transfer, etching, scrubbing and then drilling holes before I get so solder.

Now you can understand why I desperately want a PCB milling machine. After I design a PCB on the computer I just want to click a button and the PCB should be ready. A PCB milling machines costs about 35000 indian rupees. But whats the fun if we can't make our own.

  1. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PInmEPY54G4
  2. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FvVjUVA_JIs
  3. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X6-DLpDx3HQ
  4. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nmZtaAHRn0I

It is easy to find small hex drivers, but harder to find small nut drivers/sockets.

This is a simple and fast print that has a nut socket on one side and a hex drive hole on the other. Insert a hex driver in the hex drive hole and you have a simple nut driver. If you size it right (for example, 2.5mm drive hole) you can have an M3 driver and then convert it to an M3 socket.

The customizer will let you adjust the sizes to suit and also has an option to scale and offset your hole sizes if you don't get exact small holes on your interiors.

I suggest a high infill (I used 33%) so they will survive some torque.

If you want to make a permanent one, make the drive hole very tight, heat up the hex driver and push it into the hole so the plastic grabs the drive shaft.

title: OCULUS RIFT VR GUN STOCK - MAGNETIC CUP, SPRING LOADED ADJUSTMENTS - ONWARD, PAVLOV, BAM, STAND OUT
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
PLEASE READ EVERYTHING, I KNOW IT'S A LOT!!!! (there's very important stuff in here)

My previous gun stock has just shy of 1500 downloads. This version is FAR superior. Redesigned from the ground up for easier printing, better stability, and the 2 best improvements, magnetic cup on right hand and spring loaded adjustable cups. No more removing your HMD to move the cups, just press the button and move!

Here is a video of it in action as well - https://youtu.be/nNE08yo8yTc

You will need to buy a handful of things to make this work. Here's a list;

Magnets - you need 2. Please note this link is for 10. The magnetic holes are designed around these size magnets so please be careful, others might not work. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072K586ZW/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Springs - Again, please note that you will only need 3 of these. Again, they are very specifically designed around this size though. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XPG813G/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Nuts and Bolts - you will need 5x #8 bolts 1.5 inch and 3 #8 nuts.

Screws - You will need 8x .5 inch screws to attach the rear plates

Rings for Strap - Any key ring will do, I used these. You only need one or two depending on if you want a one point or two point strap. Also, I just used little plastic parts to attach the rings to the screws in the butt and the front bolt respectively. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N6L7DGA/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

One thing of note, as of this time I haven't QUITE got a reliable trigger for holding the cheekrest in place. Truth be told I don't use the adjustable cheekrest but I know others do so if you come up with a good option in the meantime let me know!

You will need to print one of everything above, except you will need 3 each of "Rail Gun - top rail.stl" and "RAIL GUN - Bottom Rail.stl"!!!!!!!!!!

ALL WALLS ARE 4mm THICK AND THIS WHOLE DESIGN IS MEANT TO BE PRINTED AT 4mm THICKNESS WITH 0% INFILL. ANY OTHER SETTINGS I CAN'T GUARANTEE!!!!

THE MAGNET IS ONLY SET UP FOR THE RIGHT HAND, SO LEFT HANDED PEOPLE OR PEOPLE WHO WANT BOTH CUPS TO BE STATIC ARE UP A CREEK FOR THE MOMENT. LEFTIES COULD STILL PRINT THIS BUT YOUR DOMINANT HAND WILL BE A STATIC CUP AND YOUR NON-DOMINANT HAND WILL BE A MAGNET CUP.

PLEASE NOTE THERE WILL BE SANDING NEEDED TO GET THESE PARTS TO FIT SNUG. NOT ALL PARTS ARE PERFECT SO MAKE SURE YOU ARE READY TO FINE TUNE IT TO GET IT TO FIT TOGETHER PROPERLY

Please note the license. DO NOT SELL this stock without my permission first. I am interested in letting someone sell this commercially though, please contact me if you are in EU or US and interested.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

0%

Notes:

WALLS ARE 4mm THICK. USE THAT WITH 0% INFILL FOR BEST RESULTS

description.text: This is to fix a problem i noticed happens when you do fast back and forth movements on the CR10 it was concerning at first, then i realized it was simply a bearing that in no way, shape, or form was big enough for the space allotted. this is a simple print that takes 10 mins and fixed the problem

comments.text: I have the cr10s and it has the 2 top bearings in a slot so they have loads of play. I first saw that and wondered if kids designed this printer. As I asked around I was told that those are like that for a reason. That reason is since the printer is not built with the mechanics with any type of tolerance they have to have play in those top bearings or if you locate them firm it will affect the quality of print. The Z axis is just not aligned well. You can try to make it better but its tough to fix something that was never built to be fixed. If you lock those bearings in place it will cause a drag on the lead screw or cause a wobble all will affect your prints. Mine rattle when printing fast so I slowed my speed down to 40mm/s and it took care of that rattle. it still vibrates so I am going to install dampeners on the steppers to eliminate the vibration.

print_settings.Notes:: I don't think infill percentage really matters, but I went higher than lower at 35%, with 5 perimeter walls for a very solid feel, and I think 1.6mm thick tops and bottoms for (again) a very solid heavy feel.

description.text:
I wanted to design a case to fit the aesthetic of the original Apple AEK keyboard for my upcoming Alps 64 build.

I plan on binding the two halves with XTC-3d, finishing with some sanding and painting to match the color of the original AEK keyboard. Each half will take around 1 day and 16 hours to print according to CURA.

UPDATE: 5 perimeter walls, 1.6mm thick bottom/top, 35% infill @ 60mm/s with my printer's acceleration settings took about 48 hours per half.

After doing a test print, I notice that the right half has a bit more of a gap between the side of the case and the keycaps when installing the board. I think the USB cutout port could be sized better, wider horizontally to allow you to correctly center your 60% PCB in this case. In my case, I just cut back the USB cutout on one side to allow my PCB to slide to the right side of the case to even out the gaps a bit.

Sharing here if anyone else is interested. I will try to remember to update this post when finished with the print and build.

Update: Check out the final product pics now... yeeeee

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

Duplicator I3 PLUS

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.8

Infill:

35

Notes:

I don't think infill percentage really matters, but I went higher than lower at 35%, with 5 perimeter walls for a very solid feel, and I think 1.6mm thick tops and bottoms for (again) a very solid heavy feel.

Sanded the PLA print with 220 grit, then 320 grit. I then used 3 coats of primer-filler to get to this point.

I had to use a razor blade to remove some of the support material left behind prior to sanding those areas.

There are still some gaps from joining the two sides with loctite super glue that I plan on filling with bondo, sanding it, along with sanding a few more imperfections that became apparent during primer application.

Finally, after bondo and sanding, I plan on doing a final coat of primer-filler, painting and clearcoating.

I ended up doing 3 coats of primer-filler after sanding, then bondo, then 2 more coats of primer filler, 3 coats of color, and 2-3 coats of matte clear.

description.text: 3d printing

print_settings.Notes:: I have tested this, and it has successfully printed a multi color print. There is a kind of "break in" period, while the feed paths wear in, but theoretically, the longer you use it, the better it should work.

title: Multiplexer redesign for Prusa Multi Material Upgrade (no brass)

description.text:
Please print with a minimum of 4 perimeter layers. This allows for the Festo fittings to be threaded without cracking.

It is highly recommended to take a "used" piece of filament (ridges help) and make sure that each feed path has no resistance. Since it is printed out of PLA, the more you work filament through each feed path, the better this should work.

There is no need for any brass press in fittings or steel tubes in the feed paths. Simply take the Festo fittings and thread them directly into the plastic. There are no threads printed into the model so you will have to force it a little to get it to start threading. I recommend using a sturdy pair of needle nose pliers so you can guide it into the correct orientation during threading. This is the only hard part of making this work. The closer you get the Festo fitting to being parallel to the feed path, the better this will work.

I have tested this, and it has successfully printed a multi color print. There is a kind of "break in" period, while the feed paths wear in, but theoretically, the longer you use it, the better it should work.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm layer height

Infill:

20% cubic

Notes:

Please print with a minimum of 4 perimeter layers. This allows for the Festo fittings to be threaded without cracking.

It is highly recommended to take a "used" piece of filament (ridges help) and make sure that each feed path has no resistance. Since it is printed out of PLA, the more you work filament through each feed path, the better this should work.

There is no need for any brass press in fittings or steel tubes in the feed paths. Simply take the Festo fittings and thread them directly into the plastic. There are no threads printed into the model so you will have to force it a little to get it to start threading. I recommend using a sturdy pair of needle nose pliers so you can guide it into the correct orientation during threading. This is the only hard part of making this work. The closer you get the Festo fitting to being parallel to the feed path, the better this will work.

I have tested this, and it has successfully printed a multi color print. There is a kind of "break in" period, while the feed paths wear in, but theoretically, the longer you use it, the better it should work.

comments.text: Everybody is free to print in whatever material they like. Personally, I've been struggling to get good structural ABS prints due to shrinkage causing cracks. Further, PLA is quite hard and rigid, both of which are probably good things for this part.

RC Rim for 1/10 Cars

Update on 1/11/18. Refreshed all files. Better routing to make it easier. I don't think a brim is needed.

The clips on top are stronger, but still has a screw in the center for better holding. Print settings were .2mm layer height, 20% infill and it looks fine. I used a brim on part A only. It can take protected 18650s, but may be tight on some, or very loose on unprotected cells.

Use solid copper wire. 22AWG is all I have right now, but 20 should work. It can work just wrapping wire, but the main connector needs more work. I melted wire into the plastic but there's probably a better way. The 3B balance pin is used in tools for battery level and that one and the middle one have a 1K resistor on the original. The resistors (1/16w) were meant to fit into the holes vertically, so the leads become the contacts (need to be larger).

comments.text: Love this design. Any suggestion on where to purchase the materials necessary to create the connectors for the batteries themselves?
comments.author: 12VoltWorkshop

comments.text: Thanks! I didn't use any hardware except for the 1 screw. The rest is all wire. I uploaded a pic of the new top. I pull solid core wire through the holes and bend them down so they're out of the way. The other 2 wires come from the bottom and connect to the center top cell and the balance taps. I keep shielding on those. You don't really need to connect the side one that connects to 1B and 3B (with resistor), or the center tap and resistor unless you plan to use the M12 charger. The hard part is getting it to fit with different cell sizes. If it's tight, it's easy.

author: pit202

title: Tronxy X5S E3D V6 Base Plate (Re-mixed)

description.text:
Still new to CAD work, and isn't the cleanest but seems to work for me as a start.
Printed with PETG, 50% infill, flat backplate side on the bed, and used supports.
Has some mesh error in the slicer which I didn't see in Blender that shows up on the fan section. Haven't come back to clean it up yet ...

Remixed starting from jebk thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2638792
Clamp for base can be found on link.

Liked the design he put up but needed some adjustments for what I wanted.
Matched the X-axis end stop up to be the same location as original, and added a SN04 auto-level mount. Also wanted more clearance from the bottom carriage wheel relative to the Z axis.

UPDATE:
Created a new base plate that cleaned up the mesh error around the fan. Also added a belt alignment feature built in on the right hand side, and a bolt on add in for the left hand side.
Belt alignment was added as I used graham01's mega gantry plate;
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594291
The consolidation of the bearings to one position created the belt offset, so between the new base plate (Tronxy_X5S_E3dv6_wBeltAlignment) and the add on (Tronxy_X5S_BeltAlignment_LeftSide_AddOn) it should be lined up pretty well.
Also I'm using kawa18's original bearing pulley;
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2610729

Here's my settings for probe offset using base plate with belt alignment;
//-----------------------Tronxy X5S SN04 sensor------------
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -45 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 3 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]
// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 290
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 310
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

author: printerDave

description.text:
In Japanese folklore the female demon (oni) Hannya figures prominently. Often depicted in traditional Noh and Bunraku plays using a wooden mask of a fierce and grimacing horned demon, this malicious entity may be Japan's most well-known demon. 
I've always been drawn to Japanese style art and find these masks fascinating.  Its my first go around making one.  I tried to stay with a traditional look while adding some of my own embelishments.  Terribly hard to not make a demon look too sinister.  I may have another go (or two) at these masks
Enjoy!

Two models included.  One is the original model as created.  It has a fairly smooth back (layer 1) and would probably print with rafting / support.
The other model has been flattened for a smooth strong bed adhesion.
The mask is oriented in a way that provides for the horns to print fairly vertical, so there shouldnt be any concerns with support. I am finding that the teeth have some overhang (I undercut them in the model...lesson learned), but I dont really think its a big deal.  
Print size is 108mm long x 80mm wide x 87mm high

I hope you like my design!

Cheers,
Paul Van Gaans

remixed_from.title: Working 5 speed transmission model for Toyota 22RE engine

title: 1/10 Scale working 5 speed transmission for 1/10 22RE motor

description.text:
Update: After checking the scale it is actually close to 1/10 scale. Maybe a little larger.

This is a remix of Ericthepoolboy's working 5 speed transmission for 22re motor. I resized the files to 1/10 sacle to work with my resized 1/10 22RE Toyota motor. Many of the files were changed to accomodate the new hardware. All the hardware used was the same as the 1/10 scale 22RE motor. Almost all parts were printed at .1 resolution. This project will test your printer, modeling skills, and your patience. It was fun.

Some of the changes are:

No washers are used. Bearings used were 5x2x2.5mm (MR52zz) acquired from Banggood.com

The shift collar gear no longer uses set screws. You must assemble the transmission and note the location of the collar gear and glue in place. Gear 1 top laso glues into place on the input shaft. If you can source small set screws i suggest you use a set screw.

The shift collar gear 5th also glues in place.

Shift forks and collar forks also glue in place after assembly. Top Rail is gears 1-2 collar fork. bottom rail is gears 3-4 collar fork. See picture for instructions.

Depending on the rod used you will have to clearance holes. I used 1.5mm and 2mm carbon fiber rods.

Shift collars outside surface that contacts the shift forksmneed to be sanded to a smooth finish. You will have to clearance the inside so it slides on the collar gears easily. I lubed all collars and transmission gears with gun grease.

If you are going to use my spur gear from the 22RE motor build you will have to shave the bell housing a lot where the pinion goes in or it will rub the bell housing and stop the motor from turning.

https://youtu.be/x5OagnD-HUs

This is not a easy build. Due to the small size and printer variances you may have to sand, flie, or ream parts for fitment. Entire project can be printed and assembled in 2 days.

• Minimal cilindrical holder for 18650.

  • It has 2 large holes per corner, these are for screwing in the cable that is used as a terminal more easily.

Try to ensure that the cables are not tightened or the battery cannot be removed.

  • Contenedor mínimo y funcional para baterías/pilas 18650.

  • Puede funcionar parado (ideal para usarlo de vela con leds en adornos), o vertical.
  • Los cables que pasan de un lado a otro pueden quedar ocultos en el diseño para que ocupe menos lugar.
  • Para usar la batería solo es necesario introducir la pila 18650 y presionar las 2 puntas (tenga en cuenta que el diseño en ambas terminales es semi esférico lo que asegura fácil contacto, como así que quede oculto los giros del cable.

remixed_from.author: TNS
remixed_from.title: ANET A8 | Customizable E3D v6 Carriage /  Bowden Mount

title: Improved Customizeable Anet A8 E3D v6 E3Dv6 Carriage with 40mm Fan Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the popular E3Dv6 Mount for the Anet A8 from TNS.

I tried to fix a few problems I had with the original design:

  • The screws had no nuts and could therefore not be tightend very well, because the hole was easily destroyed. I solved this by adding hexagonal holes you can fit nuts in. The cap is being attached by 1cm long nuts.

  • The hole for attaching the bearing holders were very tight and had almost no clearance. Therefore you could not really adjust to your axles which made it very hard to get a low sliding resistance. I solved this by making the holes for the lower bearing holder longer so that they have a clearance of 4mm. They are automatically adjusted to your personal setup while tightening the screws.

  • It was hard using the stock 40mm fan for cooling instead of the 30mm fan from the E3Dv6. All mounts I could find work by clipping the fan mount onto the radiator which is not really tight (It rattles) and blocks a large area of the radiator for the air flow. I solved this by attaching the fan mount directly to the cap that holds the extruder. Since this one is screwed to the backplate, it holds really tight and the fan mount only blocks exactly one half of the radiator for the air flow which gives the best possible cooling effect.

Overall I think the improvements turned out very well. I'm really happy with the way it works now. I hope you like it too.

I remained all the customization options from the original Mount by TNS. I tested most of the settings on interferences with my changes and could not find any. In case you find an interferance, please write me a comment and I'll try to fix it.

If you like it, you may also check out my other Anet A8 and 3d printing things:

  • Customizeable Cooling Fan Blades
  • Filament Guides for the Anet A8 in 6 variations (0°, 45°, 90°) Vertical and Horizontal
  • Anet A8 - Original X Axis Mounts V2
  • Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU - IGUS like - with mount
  • Spoolhoder tube to lower rotational resistance (requires two axle bearings)
  • Cable Clip (Anet like)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

Since the Mount carries the extruder it should be pretty solid. therefore I printed it at 50%. Usally PLA is stable enough as long as you are not printing in a closed case. For the backplate supports or rafts are not necessary. The original cap without fan mount can also be printed without rafts or supports. The cap with the fan mount requires support structures and a raft might be helpful since its base is pretty small.

After the print you have to fit all the nuts into the hexagonal holes. The fits are tight so that the nuts don't just fall out. If you are unable to fit the nuts into the holes try pulling it in with a screw and use a hot air gun to soften the material a bit.

Mosty regular M3 nuts are used. Only the nuts that hold the cap are 1cm long ones, because the corresponding screws shall not exceed the backplate to keep space for the belt attacher.

I redesigned the cap so that you can use the M3 torx scres that come with the printer.

comments.text: Hello Triple_s
comments.author: bulderhund

comments.text:
I have not optimized my settings yet. They are all just values that work very well for me, but there might be better ones.
My retraction is currently set to 5mm at 100mm/s. For the speed I'm using 30 mm/s for slow, 60 mm/s for regular and 150 mm/s for travel. I think there are definitly larger speeds possible, but therefore I would need a geared extruder, because at 60 mm/s the extruder motor reaches it's maximum strength pushing the filament towards the nozzle.
You might try 70 mm/s or even 80 mm/s - I have not optimized my values, because the ones I'm using are working very well for me. And never change a running system XD

title: Shaving Supplies Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are a series of elegant display stands for the Harry's brand shaving supplies.

Provided are the files for 3 different adaptations:

"fullOnePiece.STL"

The standard 130mm by 160mm arrangement featuring:

  • 1 holder for shave gel
  • 1 holder for post-shave balm
  • 1 holder for the Truman handle
  • 2 holders for vertically stored 4x 5-blade cartidges
  • 1 holder for a horizontally stored 4x 5-blade cartidge
  • A simple backing to compliment the Truman handle
  • Sleek, guided water exit pathways in every holder

In order to minimize the support structures, time, and material required to print this part, the following pieces form a 2 part alternative to the "fullOnePiece" above:
"fullTwoPiecesPart1.STL"
"fullTwoPiecesPart2.STL"
Please see Post-Printing for assembly instructions.

"minimalistic.STL"

The standard 130mm by 160mm arrangement featuring:

  • 1 holder for shave gel
  • 1 holder for post-shave balm
  • 1 holder for the Truman handle
  • 2 holders for vertically stored 4x 5-blade cartidges
  • Sleek, guided water exit pathways in every holder

"compromise.STL"

The standard 130mm by 160mm arrangement featuring:

  • 1 holder for shave gel
  • 1 holder for post-shave balm
  • 1 holder for the Truman handle
  • 2 holders for vertically stored 4x 5-blade cartidges
  • A half-height sleek backing for the Truman handle that conceals the 2 cartridges
  • Sleek, guided water exit pathways in every holder

Notes:

Corner warping of the first few layers is common in parts with large flat-bottomed surfaces. Please be sure to consider the temperature of the heated bed, as well as the speed and cooling of the extruder head to minimise this effect. The bed surface I used is included for reference.

Supports:
Please use them as you see fit. I needed supports for the "fullOnePiece.STL" horizontal cartridge holder and the "fullTwoPiecePart1.STL" joining slot.

Printer: Custom CoreXY build

Slicer: Simplify3D

Material: Hatchbox PLA

Rafts: None - See Bed Surface

Layer Height - 0.3mm

Infill: 18% Fast Honeycomb

Nozzle Temperature: 210 degrees celsius

Bed Temperature: 55 degrees celcius

Bed Surface: PrintInZ build surface

"fullTwoPieces" parts 1 and 2

After printing both pieces, the objective is to insert the flat end of the part 2 (the horizontal cartridge holder) into the obvious slit in part 1. To do this, sanding down the flat end of part 2 is recommended before gluing the two pieces together. Glue may not be required if the tolerance after sanding is low enough.

Design Process

These models were all designed in Fusion360.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

After the success of the water dish I wondered how a food dish could work with a Gatorade
bottle. Well here it is.

I originally printed this on 12/14/2017, I found out right away that the size of the kibble I
had caused a log jam at the neck of the bottle. I then designed the pivot piece to hopefully
rectify the situation. After a few days the cats were able to figure it out and they are now
able to empty the bottle in about 3-4 days. Which is about how much I can fit in a 32oz
bottle based on what I was giving them on a daily bases.

After witnessing one of the cats head butt the bottle to make it tilt the other way and have
food dispense, I decided it was time to publish it. I suspect that smaller kibble will not
need the pivot piece.

01/09/2018 I just added the funnel for quick filling the bottle. It works well when pouring on to it, next refill I will test how it does scooping directly out of the bag. At 25% infill, this one seems plenty sturdy to do this.

description.text:
Front bumper broke at my Asso (Team Associated) RC car 1/10. No change to get a new one before our race so I designed one and here it is.

I have designed 2 different covers, one original version and one with a special hole for our race transponders. I have printed this in black Polymaker PolyMax PLA which is realy strong, no damage so far after a really tough race.

The "ramp", I call it support needs to be glued to the bottom to flat down the edge.

The original cover also fits to the base, as seen on my pictures.

I have added the STEP files that you are able to modify as needed.

CR-10

Yes

0.2

100%

Notes:

I recommend Polymaker PolyMax PLA which is really strong

print_settings.Notes:: Print with a brim of 0.00mm offset and 6 skirt outlines to stop the part lifting / warping.

title: Retrocade - Display Screen Panel in two easy print parts

description.text:
Even though my A8 can print 220 x 220 it really struggled with this panel.

So I've split the panel at the bulkiest part and when printed I simply use a soldering Iron to join the two together by melting the PLA at the raised "slide" part that is behind the panel. (so you can't see the solder joined bits)
It does leave a visible line, but most people use vinyl covering anyway, or paint it.

Careful not to melt the "V" shaped slot or the screen lock panel won't slide in.

(In the photo's the left side is "burned" as my iron was too hot. Dialed it down for the right one.)

Everything else prints just fine on the Anet A8. (Except the back door - See my other things!)

Print at 0.4 and 30% infill and it's sturdy enough.

Kudos to @christan for this awesome design!!! (https://www.thingiverse.com/christan)

Enjoy!

Anet A8

I've cut the Tardis into three pieces that means no overhangs :) Easy to print and glue together

printed in sainsmart 95a tpu
using an anycubic i3 mega ultrabase

while it is not perfect it does work, i have tested for 2 flights and bashed it around a lot.
i was using cable ties before and they worked just as well but i wanted a more complete look.
the short part is for the ground or non activated part of the antenna and the long for the activated part. its tricky to get the activated dipole down the tube but i used tweezers and just pushed it from the hole in the underside if the antenna then slid the full thing down. i also added some strain in the non activated part for cold days when the tpu is at its hardest.
the antenna is set at 30 degrees to allow for my forward flight angle.

comments.author: DavidNBK

comments.text: The only thing I did before exporting the new models was to import the inventor file into Fusion 360 before exporting so the model hasn't changed in any way. To be sure I just did a test where I imported the original STL file into the same project and they match exactly.
comments.author: DavidNBK

comments.text: I had to modify the design a bit since the 2 mm pegs were a bit too large to fit into the holes on the camera PCB board.  I made them 1.5 mm in diameter which leaves a bit of wiggle room.  The ideal size is somewhere in between.
comments.author: bobthechemist

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback! I haven't had any issues with that myself, but I've noticed slice settings might affect tolerances.
comments.author: bobthechemist

comments.text: Yeah, I had to trim them a bit, too. One side just fit, but the other didn't, and I didn't want to force it. Also, I didn't have the right bolt, so I made those holes a bit bigger (with a dremel: Build first, measure second...)
comments.author: atleberg

comments.text: I've added the design files (.f3d and .igs) so you can change the tolerance. The lid has a tolerance of .25mm at the moment - which works great for my printers combined with PLA. I haven't tried ABS, but I've seen people using a higher tolerance of .3mm for ABS parts.

comments.text: Thanks for the f3d files!! I had already started another one from scratch as, like you said, trying to edit STL files is not something I have mastered. Your design is almost what I needed so the design files will help me get there faster. Thanks again. Well done.

I want to install a reasonable cable management in my 3D printing cabinet. What is closer than the channels to print. Sneakypoo was so friendly to design one that I just had to enlarge. The STL files are not completely bug free so only Cura was able to slice the files properly. I had set the filling at the first pressure to 10% which is too little. The vertical bars break too easily. I think 60% are better.

Ich will in meinen 3D-druck schrank ein vernünftiges Kabelmanagement einbauen. Was liegt da näher als die Kanäle zu Drucken. Sneakypoo war so freundlich einen zu entwerfen den ich nur vergrößern musste. Die STL dateien sind nicht ganz fehlerfrei so das nur Cura in der lage war die Dateien vernünftig zu Slicen. Die Füllung hatte ich beim ersten Druck auf 10% gesetzt was aber zu wenig ist. Die senkrechten Stäbe brechen zu leicht weg. Ich Denke 60% sind besser.

Model is 250mm high, though it should increase ok if needed but I haven't check any of the tolerances.

I spit https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054299 light saber down to make a stand for a Kylo Ren mask that I have printed.

I have designed a base for this print to sit on using a strong magnet at the base of the light saber.

The bottom section should be printed upside down to lessen the amount of support needed.
The middle section should be printed up right with plenty of support to keep the detail of the handle.
The top section can be printed upright but will need support for the arms.

The split down top is to save time and support for the arms. The arms have been added separately and they are sided.
I have not printed the split down version and I am unaware what the fitment is like, though it look good in tinkercad.

Thanks to https://www.thingiverse.com/Grandaltoclaripipebone for letting me remix this.

title: CR-10s Digital depth gauge holder for bed levelling

description.text:
I buyed a digital depth gauge for levelling the bed of my CR-10S, but printable holders found on line do not fit my gauge
This is 2 part print that must be glue together (see picture for final assembly)
Print with your everyday settings, glue with CA et voila.

One note... this type of digital gauge, as opposed to the dial type, require a use of a rubber band for pull down the needle.
Alternatively, you can remove the spring that stiffen the needle (it require you remove the 4 screws under the sticker on the rear, remove the cover, then take apart the needle. the spring is a flat metallic sheet underneath the needle plastic).

This model is one whose modeling steps are detailed in my book Modeling in SketchUp for 3D Printing. It's basically a ladder with sides and rungs, twisted using the FredoScale plugin.

Start by printing two sides and four rungs. (If you have a dual extruder, print the rungs in two colors.) Place the rungs in one sides first, then gently attach the second side to the other side of the rungs, starting from the top and working your way to the bottom. Print several sets of rungs and sides and stack them up. Make sure you have two supports printed, if you want your DNA ladder to stand.

comments.author: Linuxglobal

description.text:
I made this flower Qi charger for my wife.
The original flower is made by bucad (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810720)
I changed the design so it can fit a smartphone, and I added a slot for a basic Qi charger.

The design is tested with an LG G4 and an Samsung Galaxy S7 edge, both with case.
If your phone is bigger you can always scale the model.

It also seems to work as amplifier for your music!

This duct provide air flow all around the nozzle but keep the user able to see what is printing. The usual duct that hide the nozzle because of the shape wich obstruct the view. With this one the shape is optimised to keep a survey area of the printing and it's very important especially at the start of the printing.
It's a small calibration square for your 3d printer.

Just print and measure for more printing fun! I made this model a little large on the XY-plane so my measurements for calibrating the printer are more accurate. dimensions: outside: 40 x 40 mm
small beam: 2,5 x 2,5 mm
larger beam: 5 x 5 mm
square block: 20x20 mm
wall-thickness: 2 mm
total height: 10 mm Mine actually showed me some backlash or slipping during print at 2,5mm and 5mm Z-height.

I found that the LM8LUU bearings allowed quite a bit of twisting movement. I tried an experiment using two LM8UU bearings and stability of the carriage improved immensely.

Consequently, I have redesigned the bearing carriers to use four LM8UUs instead of two LM8LUUs. I have also redesigned the target cooling duct to have a single duct, the other arm now being used to mount a Tronxy square proximity sensor as close to the nozzle as possible (Offset is 38.5mm). The heatsink duct has also been redesigned to mount a 40mm fan instead of the stock 30mm. The target cooler also has a ring duct.

Another few small improvements are the nut traps to make assembly a lot easier than the original, a bracket on the front right bearing carrier to cable tie the cable bundle and I've hollowed out the bearing carriers to lighten them without compromising strength.

If you like, you can use the original bearing carriers at the front and have 2 X LM8UU at the back and 1 X LM8LUU at the front, as even this improved stability greatly.

comments.text:
Thanks for this project. I love it so i can use drylin RJ4JP-.
I have just a question. Why did you make it so wide? there is a lot of space between the two bearings.
Wouldn't be better to have smaller and lighter parts?
Thank you
comments.author: acefigo

comments.text: The further apart the bearings are, the more stable the carriage is. I designed this in such a way that while there is a decent amount of physical separation between the bearings, the carriages still do not protrude beyond the target ducts (If using the bifurcated duct) or the target duct and sensor (If using the single target duct/sensor mount).

author: MarcusMoeller

print_settings.Notes:: All parts should print without support in the orientation I uploaded.  The Z endstop mount may need a brim.

description.text:
My Zonestar Z5MR2 came without a mount for the X endstop. The cable for the Z endstop didn't match the switch that was mounted to the frame. The Y endstop allowed the bed to home too far back, limiting the bed position that was useable. These parts are my fixes for these problems. I will add more pieces for extruder mounting, ZRIB cover, & cable management as I develop those pieces.
The Z endstop mount is specific to the microswitch I used to replace the one from the factory. The factory switch came with a 4 pin connector & the wiring loom had a 3 pin connector. I saw that the X & Y stops only used 2 wires, so I made my Z stop the same. It mounts to the same holes as the stock one, but is non-adjustable (does not use the screw for setting home position)
The X endstop mount adds a hole for ziptie to attach the cable for strain relief. You should be able to mount it with all the factory hardware. Position it so that the nozzle will be over the bed when sent a G0 X0. The homing position for my printer was about -28mm
The Y endstop replaces one of the spacers for the wheels under the Y carriage & contacts the little "button" on the microswitch. Before the acrylic carriage just ran into the "arm" on the microswitch. Now Y0 is right at the front edge of the bed instead of 20mm in front of it!
01-14-2018 added mount to tilt extruder motors 45 degrees forward - reducing curve of Bowden tubes & moving incoming filament path up & away from wiring.

Prusa

Printer:

description.text:
I got the aluminium case and the 24v smpsu and the stc t12 board, but when i assembled everything- the board fits too tight and the rear plug bumps to the board.

So i designed these spacera to sit between the back panel and case - similarly for the front !
the longest one is the front one

then drill holes accordingly - voila

enjoy

As for the t12 board - my vibration did not work at first. i got my old ersa and re soldered all the board/ now works like a treat !

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gMM9NqFfZ2h

A cover for UNI-T light sensor (UT383 BT)
I have printed the first file in ABS and it was a little bit bigger from the sensor.
so I have tweaked the tooth with hot air to hold the sensor.

I add a new file with tighter tolerances but I didn't print it!!

I'll be happy to hear if it good for your sensor.

main dimensions in the PDF files

Calibration help for Peopoly MOAI 3D printer
Because I use different resins, I use for each resin a different vat for the MOAI printer.
The problem is that there are small differences between the vat's.
And the calibration is not easy.
That's why I made a calibration help that can be clamped on the building plate.
see picture 1

This calibration help can be 3Dprinten and with some m3 screws and 4 ballpoint springs it is easy to make.
It now take a few minutes to calibrate the vat. (I have the left side of the printer closed with two screws so it can be easily opened, to turn the nuts that calibrates the vat)

Steps to use this Moai calibration help;
Clamp the calibration helper on the left and right side of the building platform.
Take a piece of paper and fold it till the thickness is about 0.2mm (I don't know if this is the best distance, but it works for me)
Put the paper on an very flat surface (glass for example).
And put the build plate with the clamped helpers over the paper, the 4 feet’s must be on the surface, not on the paper.
Press on the build plate and turn on the wingnuts till the points are on the same height.
See picture 2

Mount the build plate, with the helpers on it, back in the printer.
see picture 1

Set in the “setup”-> “advanced “ the Z the “Z Reset Position” on 188 (sometimes you must set it first on 187 and then again on 188 before it moves).
The build plate is going to his position in the vat.
Remove the side plate of the printer, so you can turn the nuts that calibrates the vat.
if it is necessary, turn the 4 nuts under the vat till the points are in the same line ( the upper arm is horizontal)
see picture 3

(A small movement of the vat in the Z direction gives a great movement of the indicator arm, so if you turn the nuts that calibrates the vat you can see clearly the displacement.)
I printed the Calibration helper on my Ultimaker2 from ABS (Innofil ABS Fusion+) and no Support or Platform adhesion. (This ABS sticks from itself on the clean glass).
Because some parts of the print are a bit fragile it is a good idea put some alcohol 96% against the print. Than it pops mostly of the glass.
see picture 4

This helper works good for me, so I hope it help you also..

title: TRONXY P802 Power Supply Switch Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Power supply switch cover that I designed for my TRONXY P802MA. The power supply (at least on the power supply that was shipped with mine) has limited holes to secure a switch enclosure to (in fact, only one near the bottom). To work around this limitation, the top of the switch enclosure wraps around the power supply, giving it the support it needs to stay in place securely.

You'll need longer bolts to mount the power supply back on the frame, along with spacers (2mm), as well as bolts and nuts to mount the switch (designed for m3 bolts, since I had those on hand).

The Switch I used can be found here:

https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XKBRT9M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00

Designed in FreeCad. FreeCad source file included. Measurements/spacing dimensions parameterized via the spreadsheet workbench.

title: Electric Igniter Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Electric Firework Igniter that uses Nichrome wire to set off firework fuses.

Items Required:
30 mm Nichrome Wire Ni80
0.5 mm 2 leads wire (length up to you)
3D Printed clip
Small Elastic Band
Pin (used to wrap Ni80 wire around to make a 6 mm long spring)
Soldering Iron & Solder
!Note: I'll post pics as soon as its ready.
Used On The Following Projects:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2726908
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722564
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722538
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2726745
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2721578
insert 2 wires with 1-2 mm of insulation removed in the 2 holes in det clip A2 . twist some Ni80 wire around a pin to make a spring that is 1-1.5mm Diameter and 6mm long, solder both ends spring to both ends of the wires add Det Clip B2 in the same orientation it is on the stl, it should pivot on top of piece A2. wrap both pieces with a small elastic band in the groove. you are left with something that looks like a clothes peg. clamp on your fuse and as soon as you attach both ends of wire to a 9v battery, the wire will get red hot and ignite the fuse, done ;)
!Don't forget to CHECK OUT my other designs and FOLLOW my daily KooKoo uploads, Enjoy ;)

0.1
