comments.text: Uruguay has a much higher per capita murder rate than the US. About 8.42 people per 100,000 are murdered each year in Uruguay where about 4.88 per 100,000 are murdered in the US which makes the murder rate in Uruguay almost double the US murder rate. The US is number 94 in the world but Uruguay is number 59 (lower numbers are bad). Uruguay has a population of about 3.44 million, The US population is about 323.1 million, almost 100 times that of Uruguay. The global average murder rate is 6.2, so the US at 4.88 is below average and Uruguay at 8.42 is above average.

description.text:
Inspiré de la pièce de Fcollingwood que je remercie au passage, j'ai modélisé et réalisé cette entretoise pour un fan Gelid (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/2-x-Pack-of-Gelid-Solutions-Silent-6-60mm-Case-Fans-3200-RPM-16-CFM-24-dBA/121197136910?hash=item1c37e98c0e:g:vIIAAOxygPtStirm).
J'ai supprimé les entretoises laiton et les ai remplacées par 4 vis CHC M3x45mm

Les ventilateurs d'origine sont de très très mauvaise qualité. N’hésitez pas à les changer pour de la bonne qualité. Vous gagnerez en silence et en efficacité de refroidissement.

description.text:
This is a polarized filter holder I designed and printed for my Leica M6 and M9 rangefinder cameras. It holds a 77MM polarized filter and fits on the end of my 50mm f/2 Summicron lens. Filter thread diameter: 77mm, Lens diameter end: 47mm. Clearances permits pressure fits of filter and on lens and can be removed easily so no screws, clamping, or other scratch inducing mechanisms are necessary! I've please a slot on the outside of the flange so that the filter effect can be seen while twisting the filter within the ring. The holder is small enough to clear the focusing square in the viewport - so focusing obstruction. This same design could be adapted easily for for other lens sizes. I designed in in Fusion 360.
Printing note: I printed it with the lens side (small diameter) facing the bed and used support.

Metal adapters glued to printed details. Camera mount ring locked with small screws (two small holes below axis of rotation)

Layer height: 0.2mm

title: Base for LEGO attachable Raspberry Pi Zero W case

description.text:
After making the "LEGO attachable Raspberry Pi Zero W case" (thing: 2732553), I thought that an interface plate for projects not made of LEGOs would extend the usefulness of the case.

The LEGO interface makes the Rpi Zero W case easily detachable, which can help with troubleshooting or the temporary use of the board in another project.

The plate attaches using two screws. It fits "real" LEGOs and the case described in "LEGO attachable Raspberry Pi Zero W case" nicely. It can also be used to create a LEGO interface on non-LEGO projects.

I made the plate in ABS.

description.text: Prism Extender

Prism Extender for surveying
Size in mm

These parts are for standing a Logitech c270 Webcam on any flat surface! The camera can tilt vertically already, and the "holder" can rotate horizontally on the "stand" easily, but with enough friction to hold after positioning. The "feet" are designed to be made with flexible material, and TPU works great to keep everything from sliding around.

Support Removal

The center of the stand does need support, and the legs may, depending on your overhang angle.

This is a replacement crank arm for a Powermatic drill press, but it will work with any 15mm shaft. OpenSCAD code is included for customization

The Powermatic shaft collar was cheap sintered metal that fell apart in my fingers. I found a 15mm shaft collar works quite well when epoxied into the arm.

title: Ring Object Storage - Dispenser / Ringhalter (customizable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE March 2018: The THINGIVERSE Customizer is broken!!!
Thingiverse shows NO SIGN OF INTEREST IN REPAIRING IT!!

Please use the pre-build version or download the OpenSCAD file and customize it all by yourself

(English text: scroll down...)

Ein generischer, zweiteiliger Halter / Spender für Ringe und "ringartige Objekte": Dichtungen, Muttern, Markierungsringe....
Die Ringe werden auf einen Dorn aufgezogen. zwei Platten oben und unten verhindern ein Herausrutschen der Ringe.

Der Clou an der Sache ist, dass durch die Konstruktionsweise das Entnehmen eines beliebigen Ringes in der "Kette" möglich ist, ohne alle oberen Ringe herunternehmen zu müssen!

Die Dimensionen des Halters lassen sich über den Customizer verändern!
Wenn du einen hergestellt hast, lass es mich über "I Made One" wissen!

Konstruiert in OpenSCAD: viel Spaß beim Remixen!

P.S.: Das vordefinierte .STL hat die richtigen Maße für die Sonicare Bürstenmarkier-Ringe.
Die gibts hier: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2528704

This is a simple 2-part Holder/Storage/Dispenser for rings and "ring-like objects".
The rings are being put over a central pin. The neat thing about this holder is the dispenser-function: You can take out any one of the rings in the "chain" without first removing the rings above it: just pull the base plates, separate the ring(s) you need, separate the two pins and remove the rings you want.
See the photos for an example of how to use it...

You can use the customizer to create your own Ring Dispenser...

The pre-defined .STL has the correct dimensions for the Sonicare Marker Rings, shown in the pictures: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2528704

Enjoy, have fun remixing and let me know when you've made one, and what for!

description.text:
Imprimante 3D XL Franken3D

Dimensions extérieures : l 45 cm x P 47.5 cm x H 51 cm
Capacité d'impression : l 29 cm x P 30 cm x H 27 cm

Voilà les éléments pour construire la Franken3D XL printer,

  • les pièces à imprimer .stl,
  • les plans côtés,
  • la liste des pièces à acheter avec les liens des sites et les prix (Imp_3d.xlsx),
  • le firmware arduino mega+ramps 1.4 (Arduino_Firmware_Ramps_14_Franken3D_en.zip),
    si vous voulez passer l'affichage de l'écran en français voir l'article du blog (http://franken3d.blog4ever.xyz/personnaliser-marlin)
  • le schéma de câblage,

author: stevetheprinter

description.text:
After downloading and printing a few part cooling fan ducts for the Ender 2, and finding them lacking I thought I'd design my own to use the existing 40mm hot end fan and an additional 40mm axial fan. There's plenty of fan choice including some very quiet options. It prints OK on it's back with about 20-22% zig zag support in Cura from the buildplate only. It mounts to the same holes as the existing fan shroud, and even with the additional fan it doesn't weigh much more than the original assembly.
Updates once I've got it fitted and fully functioning.
And apologies for any odd or poorly thought out features! This is the first time I've used Fusion 360 or Meshmixer, and the first thing I've designed in a proper CAD package. It's been a steep learning curve over the past few days!

Improved version Uploaded (EnderDuctV3PTD) with thicker walls on the long duct, and better fillets now I've got better with Meshmixer.

comments.text:
Either I need to check some calibration on my printer (e steps), get better fans or this just did not print well for me.
I do not feel much air getting to the nozzle area to be able to cool the part AND the air ducts at the bottom do not go down far enough for me to even think that it would get air to the material to cool it down IF there was enough air getting through.
